question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

The gas-phase decomposition of iodoethane, $\ce{C2H5I}(g)$, is represented above. The bond enthalpies for the bonds broken and formed in the reaction are shown below.

$\text{Bond}$ | $\text{Bond enthalpy} \\ (\text{kJ/mol})$
:-: | :-:
$\ce{H-I}$ | $299$
$\ce{C-H}$ | $413$
$\ce{C-C}$ | $348$
$\ce{C=C}$ | $615$
$\ce{C-I}$ | $240$

**Using the information above, determine the value of ${\Delta H\degree}_{\kern-0.4emrxn}$ for the decomposition reaction.**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\text{kJ/mol}_{rxn}$

options.alt: A chemical reaction in which a reactant forms 2 products. The reactant is a Lewis structure showing 2 carbons single bonded to each other. C 1 is bonded to 3 hydrogens. C 2 is bonded to 2 hydrogens and to iodine. Product 1 is a Lewis structure showing 2 carbons double bonded to each other. Each carbon is also bonded to 2 hydrogens. Product 2 is a Lewis structure showing a hydrogen bonded to iodine.

hints.content:
The enthalpy change for a reaction can be estimated using bond enthalpies and the following equation:

$\Delta H\degree_{\kern-0.4emrxn} = \sum(\text{enthalpies of bonds broken}) - \sum(\text{enthalpies of bonds formed})$

Let’s start by identifying which bonds are broken and which are formed in the decomposition reaction. According to the diagram, one $\ce{C–H}$ bond, one $\ce{C–C}$ bond, and one $\ce{C–I}$ bond are broken in the reactant, $\ce{C2H5I}$. In the products, one $\ce{C=C}$ bond is formed in $\ce{C2H4}$ and one $\ce{H–I}$ bond is formed in $\ce{HI}$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A chemical reaction in which a reactant forms 2 products. The reactant is a Lewis structure showing 2 carbons single bonded to each other. C 1 is bonded to 3 hydrogens. C 2 is bonded to 2 hydrogens and to iodine. One of the carbon-hydrogen bonds on C 1, the carbon-carbon bond, and the carbon-iodine bond are shown in red. Product 1 is a Lewis structure showing 2 carbons double bonded to each other. Each carbon is also bonded to 2 hydrogens. Product 2 is a Lewis structure showing a hydrogen bonded to iodine. The double bond and the hydrogen-iodine bond are shown in blue.

hints.content:
Now, let’s use this information, along with the bond enthalpies in the table, to find ${\Delta H\degree}_{\kern-0.4emrxn}$:

$\begin{align}
\Delta H\degree_{\kern-0.4emrxn} &= (\text{BE}_{\ce{C-H}} + \text{BE}_{\ce{C-C}} + \text{BE}_{\ce{C-I}}) - (\text{BE}_{\ce{C=C}} + \text{BE}_{\ce{H-I}})
\\\\
&= (\pu{413 kJ/mol} + \pu{348 kJ/mol} + \pu{240 kJ/mol}) - (\pu{615 kJ/mol} + \pu{299 kJ/mol})
\\\\
&= 87\; \text{kJ/mol}_{rxn}
\end{align}$
So, the value of ${\Delta H\degree}_{\kern-0.4emrxn}$ for the decomposition reaction is $87\; \text{kJ/mol}_{rxn}$.
